任务完成：特朗普喜欢苹果的计划，尤其是关于墨西哥的一部分，我认为不是真实的
entry.content:
迈克·艾伦（Mike Allen）为阿克西奥斯（Axios）写信，标题为“特朗普制造胜利：苹果将在美国花5000亿美元，雇用20,000美元”：

特朗普周四在椭圆形办公室与库克会面。然后，特朗普感到非常兴奋，以至于他过早地揭示了计划，并在与州长会面时说，库克正在“投资数千亿美元。我希望他已经宣布了这一点 - 我希望我没有宣布，但是到底是什么？我要做的就是说实话 - 这就是他告诉我的。现在他必须这样做，对吗？”

特朗普继续说：“他也投资了数千亿美元。” “我们将有很多芯片制造商进来，很多汽车制造商进来。他们在墨西哥停止了……开始建造的两家植物。他们只是停止了他们 - 他们将在这里建造它们，因为他们不想支付关税。关税很棒。”

我敢肯定，苹果和蒂姆·库克（Tim Cook）很高兴在今天宣布以这种方式将其描绘成“特朗普制造的胜利”，尽管事实上，这似乎完全符合Apple的轨迹，因为Apple为我们创造了就业机会2018年，包括2021年几乎相同的公告（它们在很大程度上但并非完全遵循）。

不过，墨西哥角度响起了我的耳朵。彭博社上也拿起了这一点，在周末的标题上，上面写着“特朗普说库克将苹果制造业从墨西哥转移到我们”。

我记得苹果在墨西哥组装的最后一件事是1995年的少数晚模型扩展了键盘II（不如其美国制造的型号，就像我用来写这件模型一样）。在随后的几十年中，我很有可能会忽略一些墨西哥制造的苹果产品，但是如果有的话，它们不是最近的。因此，我怀疑蒂姆·库克（Tim Cook）上周在与特朗普的会议上卖给了他一份商品，或多或少地说服了特朗普，苹果公司一直计划在墨西哥委托一些新植物（一个如此讨厌特朗普的国家，也没收了他们的海湾） ，由于特朗普总统鼓舞人心的领导，苹果将在美国大红色的德克萨斯州大红色州建造这些植物 - 实际上，所有这些都完全是苹果一直在计划做的事情。

entry.title: 苹果宣布计划在未来四年内在美国花费超过5000亿美元（这可能正是他们一直在计划做的事情）
entry.content:
苹果新闻编辑室：

苹果今天宣布了有史以来最大的支出承诺，计划在未来四年内在美国支出和投资超过5000亿美元。

当然，在这一宣布方面做出了重要意义的背景是，苹果正在寻求免税特朗普政府的关税。甚至5000亿美元的资金也是很多钱，即使对于苹果来说，在未来四年中，有20,000个新工作是很多工作，尤其是在许多大型科技公司裁员而不是雇用的时候。 （如果您还没有听说，联邦政府也试图解雇很多员工。）但是，正如WSJ在此公告中的故事中所指出的那样，这20,000个新工作是他们现有的招聘增长的延续：“截至9月，公司拥有164,000名全职员工，在过去的五年中，每年平均增加5400名。”

苹果四年前宣布了类似的计划 - 4,300亿美元和20,000个工作岗位。 苹果在宣布2021年计划的宣布中说：“在过去的三年中，苹果在美国的捐款大大超过了该公司在2018年的最初五年目标。”

因此，我认为这一消息根本不是胡说八道。但是我也认为，如果卡马拉·哈里斯（Kamala Harris）在11月的少数州中获得了1-2％的选票，那么苹果今天宣布的今天与他们将要做的事情大不相同。不同之处在于，每个人都在寻求交易额，总统返回办公室。

再次苹果：

作为其新投资的一部分，Apple将与制造合作伙伴合作，于今年晚些时候在休斯敦开始生产服务器。一个250,000平方英尺的服务器制造工厂将于2026年开放，将创造数千个就业机会。

以前在美国以前生产的服务器很快将在休斯敦组装，在为Apple Intelligence提供动力方面起着关键作用，并且是Private Cloud Compute的基础，将强大的AI处理与有史以来最先进的安全架构结合在一起云计算。苹果工程师将服务器汇集了多年的研发，并将苹果硅的行业领先安全和性能交付到数据中心。

有趣的是，大型制造新闻是苹果甚至没有销售的产品，而仅用于其自己的使用。我不认为这暗示他们可能会再次出售服务器，但是谁知道呢？我也想知道，在这里而不是在中国，是否有一个公司 - 高级安全角度来组装这些服务器。

★

我们一直在寻找改善客户服务体验的方法。这种支持产品旨在提供更多的数字选项，以减少解决查询的时间。

有旋转，然后只是秃头撒谎。显然，这与改善客户支持无关，而仅仅是关于成本。惠普因此想阻止客户使用电话支持来接触真实的人寻求帮助，以便他们建立了15分钟的点球超时，以阻止人们等待。

entry.title: 莱纳斯·塞巴斯蒂安（Linus Sebastian）改用iPhone 30天后的想法
entry.content:
自从12月发行以来，我一直在意思，链接到“ Linus Tech Tips”名声的Linus Sebastian的这段视频，并且本周iPhone 16e下降了，现在似乎是个好时机。这是一种常见的流派，可以追溯到YouTube甚至是一件事之前的几十年：平台X的长期用户切换到竞争对手平台y几周，然后解释他们喜欢的东西，他们没有的东西，什么，他们混淆了等等。某种事情总是会引起攻击，因为人类自然而然地倾向于对一个人的首选平台获取部落（即使不是彻头彻尾的宗教）。塞巴斯蒂安（Sebastian）的介绍（播放YouTube的算法）以某种方式将其构图似乎使他对iOS的总体看法将是炎症的。他说，就在20分钟视频的前30秒内：

在我的iOS挑战赛几天后，我开始对我一生中的苹果用户有所不同。他们描述了苹果产品的营销口号，例如“它只是有效的”，就好像他们真的相信他们一样，这让我感到奇怪，苹果公司对真正的信徒有一个版本的产品，然后对像我这样的磨砂膏有不同的产品？因为我在iPhone 16 Plus上的时间绝对充满了不直觉的设计选择，功能不必要的功能以及我多年来遇到的一些最奇怪的错误。

我第一次观看视频时，我的手指在这一点上开始徘徊在封闭式按钮上。但是，这个挑衅的开放并不能真正代表塞巴斯蒂安的实际观察和抱怨。这只是YouTube/社交媒体风格。我？我会以最少的炎症方式开始一篇文章，例如，以最少的炎症方式打扰我，以开放人们的思想，并获得尽可能多的Android支持者放松身心，并听取我的论点。然后，我会尝试提出案例，建立一个渐强的措施，在那里我只能在最后得出炎症结论。 YouTube的工作方式相反 - 您以挑衅性的方式开始，以提高骇客，因为愤怒会促进参与度，但随后又回到了合理的方向上。

塞巴斯蒂安（Sebastian）是一位长期的Android用户，但他根本不是一个电话。通常，他通常不会审查手机。他自己的个人Android手机已经使用了几年。他的兴趣和知名度完全在PC领域。因此，他的视频并不是真正的“ Android Power用户评论iOS ”，而是“也是Android用户也尝试一个月的PC Power用户”。

我喜欢这些视频，因为此时我全面介绍了iOS。自2010年Google Nexus One以来，我一直在桌子上保留了一部Android手机，但仍然在我的桌子上的那部是五岁的像素4。在Android上比以往任何时候因此，这样的视频是从与围栏iPhone一侧的最先进的人过时的人的角度来看，这真的很有趣。

塞巴斯蒂安（Sebastian）结束了对iOS和iPhone体验的精明批评。他们都不是我的新手，他们都没有真正让我因不加入Android的一员而失去任何东西。但是他的大多数抱怨都是完全合法的 - 其中很多是苹果应该解决的问题。他反复抱怨iOS的动画过渡，使一切感觉都很慢。这是100％真实的。作为日常iPhone用户，我完全习惯了。但是这些动画确实使iPhone感觉比它们慢。就技术规格而言，iPhone实际上是地球上最快的手机。苹果的A系列硅曾经，而且一直比最好的硅货币在Android手机中购买的数年要领先数年。但是，由于iOS（NOR IPADOS）无需选择加速的动画过渡，因此iOS的许多方面都比Android慢。它应该。并且可以完全关闭动画的可访问性设置无法解决问题；我想要的，我认为塞巴斯蒂安想要什么，是更快的动画。 （Sebastian还合理地抱怨这样的事实是，许多有用的iOS设置都被掩埋在可访问性下。可访问性的许多设置与可访问性有关，但是其中许多设置在“高级”部分中可以找到，而这些设置的“高级”设置中，这些设置不是没有可访问性的。存在。）

塞巴斯蒂安还正确地将iOS串成令人困惑的音量设置； Android肯定会在这里获胜。重新布置的主屏幕图标很吸引iOS。 Carplay有烦人的错误。我的新鲜眼睛被我的刚刚接受的东西感到恼火：苹果的第一方应用程序倾向于将其偏好设置放在设置应用程序中，但是第三方应用程序往往会将其及其应用。 （但是现在，苹果也开始使用像Sports这样的新应用程序来做到这一点。）

给视频手表。再说一次，这并没有让我在栅栏的Android方面造成嫉妒的嫉妒，但它使我想起了iOS上的一堆东西，这些东西没有任何意义，而且看来它们的方式仅仅是因为那就是他们一直以来的样子。

★

entry.title: MacWorld Expo的40周年纪念日
entry.content:
吉姆·雷（Jim Rea）：

四十年前，今天的大门开放了旧金山布鲁克斯大厅地下室的第一个MacWorld博览会。对于你们大多数人来说，这个事件似乎似乎是古老的历史，回到了时代的薄雾中。但是对我来说，这是我作为参展商参加的一个非常真实和令人兴奋的活动，这是我与Mac社区的惊人旅程的开始，这一旅程持续了今天。

我记得第一年有两个或三打软件摊位。展出的一些软件包括Multiplan （Microsoft）， PFS：文件，智囊团， FileVision ， Mac插槽， Habadex ， Mac Draft ，Mac Lion， Mac Lion ， Music Works ， Click Art ，当然还有过多发行（今天的Panorama X的直接前身） 。当然，除两家公司（Microsoft）和证明发展外，所有这些公司早已消失了。我会说那是一个非常不错的俱乐部。

从那时到现在，我能够每天都在Macintosh数据库业务中继续进行证明发展，我感到非常自豪。当然，我从1984年开始使用的基于RAM的数据库概念仍然是该软件的核心。实际上，如果您查看从1984年开始的原始票面镜头，以及2025年的Panorama X，那么家庭相似之处是明确的。左侧是使用原始Mac ROM的68K装配代码，右边是AppKit的Objigtion-C，但概念是相同的。甚至还有一些数据库从左侧一直向右传播到右侧 - 连续使用四十年！

有老式的Mac开发人员仍然很强大，而且旧学校Mac开发人员仍然很强大。我不确定这家“ Microsoft”公司，但是在这里证明的成就非常了不起。阅读REA的40％折扣代码，以庆祝这个40周年。 （另外，在1984年的1.0版本中查看屏幕截图和那些疯狂的菜单栏标题。）

★

苹果在今天早上发给媒体的非常精确的措辞陈述中：

苹果不再向新用户提供英国的高级数据保护（ADP），而当前的英国用户最终将需要禁用此安全功能。 ADP使用端到端加密保护iCloud数据，这意味着只有拥有数据的用户才能解密数据，并且只能在其受信任的设备上进行解密。我们感到非常失望的是，鉴于数据泄露和对客户隐私的其他威胁，ADP提供的保护将无法为我们的客户提供。通过端到端加密增强云存储的安全性比以往任何时候都更加紧迫。苹果仍然致力于为我们的用户提供最高的个人数据安全性，并希望我们将来能够在英国的情况下这样做。正如我们以前多次说过的那样，我们从未为我们的任何产品或服务建立后门或主钥匙，我们永远也不会。

这是两周前约瑟夫·梅恩（Joseph Menn）在《华盛顿邮报》（Washington Post）和《金融时报》中蒂姆·布拉德肖（Tim Bradshaw）的消息（引用Menn的报告，重点添加）：

熟悉此事的人们告诉《华盛顿邮报》，英国的安全官员要求苹果创建一个后门，使他们能够检索所有苹果用户已上传到云的所有内容。上个月发布的英国政府未公开的命令要求覆盖能力以查看完全加密的材料，而不仅仅是在破解特定账户方面的协助，并且在主要民主国家中没有已知的先例。 [...]

内政大臣办公室已为苹果公司提供了名为“技术能力通知”的文件，命令它根据《 2016年英国扫地调查权法》提供访问权限，该法案授权执法部门在需要收集证据的情况下强迫公司援助说。该法律被批评家称为《窥探者宪章》，这使得政府甚至提出了这种要求是刑事犯罪。苹果发言人拒绝发表评论。

根据定义，端到端的加密可以没有秘密的后门，因此遵守英国的此命令，将要求苹果放弃端到端的加密 - 不仅适用于英国的用户，而且所有用户都在全球所有国家。 1更阴险和令人痛苦的是，他们显然被英国法律所禁止，受到严厉的罚款（监禁），甚至不愿告知公众这一需求，或者，如果他们要遵守，则不愿告诉公众对他们所做的事情。英国希望苹果在没有苹果告诉任何人（包括美国政府）的情况下秘密访问所有iCloud数据，即他们已经授予了英国政府这种令人叹为观止的访问权限。

苹果不是遵守苹果，而是选择从英国提取高级数据保护。对于尚未使用ADP的英国用户，在发送Apple的声明之前已经关闭了启用它的能力。英国广播公司新闻的这份报告提供了屏幕截图，其中包括英国用户今天尝试启用它的内容。

在上面重新阅读了Apple的陈述，我已经完全引用了包括超链接在内的全部引用。引人注目的是，苹果没有提供任何解释，甚至没有提示，为什么该公司“不再向新用户提供英国的高级数据保护（ADP），而当前的英国用户最终将需要禁用此安全功能” 。关于与安全和隐私有关的问题，Apple始终尽可能地解释其政策和功能。苹果没有提示为什么他们这样做的事实是一种金丝雀说明：他们明确表明他们是在法律堵嘴的命令下，以阻止他们甚至承认他们'根据法律堵嘴的命令，不告诉我们为什么他们不再能够在英国提供ADP。这类读者之间隐含的确认是，他们在堵嘴命令下是他们合法提供的唯一确认，面临监禁的风险。

启用ADP是受控的服务器端，因此Apple能够禁用英国用户在不需要对设备进行软件更新的情况下打开ADP的能力。但是，这是一个悬而未决的问题，对于已经启用ADP的英国用户将如何发挥作用。苹果不能远程禁用ADP。有了一会儿的想法，您可以意识到为什么他们不能：这将击败整个目的。就像Apple无法掌握自己的钥匙以用ADP解密用户数据一样，他们也无法保持禁用ADP的能力。

但是，启用ADP是可逆的。打开它后，用户可以将其恢复为标准保护，并将其关闭。但是他们必须手动确认。我怀疑苹果公司将为已经启用ADP的英国用户做什么是开始发出警告，指示他们在截止日期之前手动禁用它。截止日期过去了，我认为苹果将不得不停止允许iCloud访问英国受ADP保护的帐户。这不会使这些用户的数据没有受到保护 - 他们只会在禁用ADP并恢复标准保护之前就失去了对同步的访问。

最重要的是，英国政府像一个专制的威权国家一样进行。那不是夸张。而且他们命令的令人叹为观止的范围 - 能够秘密地偷偷摸摸，恕不另行通知，他们甚至具有能力，不仅对自己的公民，而且全世界的每个苹果用户都表现出了妄想的信念，即大英帝国仍然存在。它同时令人发指，数学上无知（关于端到端加密的性质），这是危险的（正如最近的盐台风袭击中国成功发动的，在美国成功地窃取了对非E2EE的通信的窃听），并且关于在美国的非E2EE通讯），以及关于天真的幼稚。英国的实际力量和地位。

苹果是正确和公义的，告诉他们要他妈的。

  1. 如果您使用高级数据保护，则只能通过自己的设备将iCloud数据解密（a），（b）使用启用ADP时控制的恢复密钥，或（c）由您创建的任何恢复联系人在iCloud。苹果坚持认为，您必须生成一个恢复密钥或指定至少一个恢复联系人才能启用ADP。丢失设备，丢失恢复密钥并丢失iCloud密码，而包括Apple在内的任何人都无法恢复您的iCloud数据。该密码保证的安全性水平是ADP的好处。这也是ADP的风险。而且有便利的费用。例如，Web访问iCloud。 引用苹果自己的ADP文档：

    当用户首先打开高级数据保护时，Web访问其在iCloud.com上的数据将自动关闭。这是因为iCloud Web服务器不再可以访问解密并显示用户数据所需的密钥。用户可以选择再次打开Web访问，并使用其受信任设备的参与来访问其在Web上的加密iCloud数据。

    打开Web访问后，用户必须在每次访问iCloud.com时都会在其受信任设备之一上授权Web登录。授权“武装”用于Web访问的设备。在接下来的一个小时中，此设备接受特定的Apple服务器的请求以上传单个服务键，但仅在ICloud.com上允许的服务列表相对应。换句话说，即使用户授权Web登录后，服务器请求也无法诱使用户的设备上传服务键的数据键，该密钥不打算在iCloud.com上查看（例如健康数据或iCloud键链中的密码）。 Apple Server仅请求使用用户要求在网络上访问的特定数据所需的服务密钥。每次上传服务密钥时，它都会使用用户授权的Web会话绑定的短暂键进行加密，并在用户的设备上显示通知，显示iCloud Service暂时可用于Apple Servers的数据。

    这是出于“我丢失了唯一的设备并忘记了我的iCloud密码”的原因，并可以轻松地通过Web访问iCloud，因此，高级数据保护并不是所有用户的默认值。

    我认为，从技术上讲，苹果有可能在典型的意义上维护“端到端加密”，同时在iCloud中的所有加密数据中添加了另一个由英国控制的签名密钥。假设您拥有两个Apple设备，一个iPhone和一个Mac，并且使用高级数据保护。您的数据只能由这两种设备或您的恢复密钥或由您的恢复联系人之一控制的设备解密。 Apple可以做一些事情，例如将英国政府添加为有效的恢复联系，向世界上加密的iCloud数据中的每个用户添加恢复联系。那仍然是“端到端”，这只是英国政府将控制其中一个终点之一。但是，iCloud安全的设计方式，不能静静地添加类似的安全性。当将新设备添加到您的iCloud帐户中时，所有现有设备都会收到已添加新设备的通知。我个人每年都会看到这些通知每年数百次，因为我在我的帐户中添加了新的审核单元设备。像9月份一样，我得到了四个iPhone 16评论单元，两个Apple Watch评论单元，并购买了自己的iPhone 16 Pro。我拥有几个Mac，几台Apple手表和一张iPad。这些设备中的每个设备中的每个设备都添加到我的iCloud帐户中，甚至只是临时用于测试，就会生成有关正在将新设备添加到我的iCloud帐户中的通知iCloud帐户。作为产品审阅者，这对我来说是一个小小的烦恼，但是当然，我别无其他方式。苹果系统的构建是使得在未经您的帐户中的每个现有设备发送到的每个现有设备的情况下，无法将新设备添加到链条中。有关新设备的通知即使在标准保护方面也会发生 - 它并不是启用ADP的用户的独特通知。

    因此，虽然从理论上讲，有些公司可以（我想？）建立一个公平（但欺骗性地）被描述为“端到端加密”的系统，其中一个“目的”是由英国政府秘密而默默地控制的，苹果公司秘密地控制了iCloud不是这样的系统。不幸的是，不幸的是，英国法律阻止苹果解释这一点，但我认为确实，苹果无法遵守英国对受ADP保护的帐户的要求，因为它们无法添加英国控制的解密密钥iCloud帐户未通知每个帐户中登录的每个设备。 ↩︎

entry.title: ★苹果从英国撤离英国对全球后门的需求，从英国撤出高级数据保护
洋基松开老板的面膜政策
entry.content:
洋基老板哈尔·斯坦布伦纳（Hal Steinbrenner）：

“最近几周，我与许多以前和现在的洋基（跨越了几个时代）进行了交谈，以引起他们对我们长期以来的面部毛发和美容政策的看法，我感谢他们的认真和多样化的反馈。这些最近的对话是持续的内部对话的延伸，可以追溯到几年。

“最终，最终的决定取决于我，经过深思熟虑，我们将修改我们的期望，让我们的球员和统一的人员可以前进。现在是超越我们以前政策熟悉的舒适的适当时机。”

适当的改变时间是几年前，但迟到总比没有好。这是最大的洋基故事，这项政策变化比今天的团队还签下了经理亚伦·布恩（Aaron Boone）在2027赛季的两年延长的事实。 MLB记者Bryan Hoch：

修饰政策可追溯到乔治·斯坦布伦纳（George M. Steinbrenner）购买该团队的政策。随着传奇的发展，它的根源在1973年发展，当时斯坦布伦纳（Steinbrenner）在对阵克利夫兰印第安人的开幕日上观察了他的球队。

Steinbrenner还不是“老板”，他的角色很新，以至于他无法通过他们的脸识别球员。取而代之的是，他专注于他们的头发 - 蓬松的胡须，羊肉排骨和蓬松的锁。他皱着眉头，在一块纸屑上乱扔统一的数字，迫切地派往经理拉尔夫·霍克（Ralph Houk）。斯坦布伦纳（Steinbrenner）指挥，告诉这些人理发。

我最喜欢的洋基唐·马廷利（Don Mattingly）不仅与乔治·斯坦布伦纳（George Steinbrenner）一起对这项政策感到悲伤，而且再次与他为下一支球队效力。

★

entry.title: 亚马逊上的芭芭拉·西兰花（Barbara Broccoli）私下：“这些人在他妈的白痴”
entry.content:
埃里希·施瓦茨（Erich Schwartzel）和杰西卡·托克尔（Jessica Toonkel）在12月19日为《华尔街日报》报道，标题为“詹姆斯·邦德在哪里？与亚马逊一起被困在一个丑陋的僵局中”（新闻+链接）：

亚马逊通过65亿美元购买Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Studio获得发行债券电影的权利将近三年，监督该专营权的家庭与电子商务巨头之间的关系几乎崩溃了。衰败的合作伙伴关系使一部新债券电影的任何近期希望 - 对好莱坞的亚马逊野心的黑眼界，因为在米高梅出售时，债券专营权代表了该公司支付的65亿美元的大量份额工作室。

当涉及到邦德的未来时，权力就在于芭芭拉·西兰花（Barbara Broccoli）的手中，芭芭拉（Barbara Broccoli）从父亲阿尔伯特·“库比（Albert“ Cubby” Broccoli）继承了控制权，他已经决定了何时一部新邦德电影可以投入制作。她告诉朋友，她不相信以算法为中心的亚马逊，她的角色通过大屏幕的讲故事和直觉来帮助神话化。今年秋天，她以可怕的方式描述了一部新电影的地位 - 没有剧本，没有故事，也没有新的纽带。

对朋友来说，西兰花已经描述了她在亚马逊上的想法：“这些人在他妈的白痴。”

显然，从僵局中出来的一种方法是出售。这是西兰花今天的公开声明， 伴随着Eon Productions达成的一项协议，将对专营权的创造性控制转移到了亚马逊：

“我的生活一直致力于维护和建立我们父亲Cubby Broccoli交给我迈克尔和我的非凡遗产。我很荣幸与四位才华横溢的演员紧密合作，这些演员曾在该行业中饰演007和成千上万的出色艺术家。在“没有时间死”的结论和迈克尔从电影中退休，我觉得是时候专注于我的其他项目了。”

西兰花的兄弟迈克尔·威尔逊（Michael Wilson）在他的陈述中稍微宽广，说：“因此，芭芭拉（Barbara）和我同意，是时候让我们值得信赖的合作伙伴亚马逊米高梅工作室（Amazon MGM Studios）带领詹姆斯·邦德（James Bond）进入未来”在她的说法中说，对亚马逊的一句话并不是一句话，威尔逊的称赞只是孤独的形容词所信任的。但是，威尔逊（Wilson）尝试略有宽容的谎言是，Eon Productions和Amazon从来都不是伴侣。在亚马逊收购之前，这是旧的米高梅工作室，这是Eon的合作伙伴（ 1963年的Dr. No ）。

我的意思是要在WSJ故事破裂时发布一个链接，并且错误地认为我有，但是它在假期周围的裂缝中滑落了。但是从那以后，我对专营权的未来有一种不好的感觉。

★

entry.title: Amazon MGM Studios对James Bond专营权进行创造性的控制
entry.content:
亚历克斯·里特曼（Alex Ritman），在综艺节目中拥有轰动一时的新闻：

亚马逊MGM Studios将对James Bond系列进行创造性的控制。震惊的宣布 - 肯定会动摇，实际上是激动的行业 - 周四发表了这一消息，即007的长期生产商和保管人迈克尔·威尔逊（Michael G.

根据历史协议的详细信息，亚马逊米高梅工作室，威尔逊和西兰花组成了一项新的合资企业，以容纳詹姆斯·邦德知识产权。这三个政党将仍然是标志性系列的共同所有人，但亚马逊米高梅将拥有创造性的控制。

邦德故事中的恶棍通常是秃头的亿万富翁工业家，他们要么建造火箭或自己的媒体公司，并在怀抱中熟悉的妇女。很难想象我们如何才能更接近现实生活中的邦德小人，以控制特许经营权。 （至少不是麝香。）

“ Nepo Babies”是一个倾向于贬义的术语，但家庭所有权是一种培养和维护（以保护具有卓越文化的杰出公司）的可靠模型。伯克希尔·哈撒韦（Berkshire Hathaway）拥有几个协议，不仅允许，而且鼓励家庭维持收购后的控制权。看到糖果的想法。沃伦·巴菲特（Warren Buffet）的这封信描述了他们的策略。但是伯克希尔本身就是一家杰出公司。大多数企业集团对创作者/家庭经营的努力的收购造成了使这些较小业务独特而特殊的一切造成的破坏。现在看看Bezos拥有它的华盛顿邮报的情况。一般而言，关于《纽约时报》，尤其是当前的出版商AG Sulzberger（自1896年Adolph Ochs购买了该报纸以来，这是第六代的家庭控制），但时代仍然是时代。

迄今为止，芭芭拉·西兰科利（Barbara Broccoli）使用007专营权做到了这一点。在她和威尔逊的生产管理下，产出不平衡，但丹尼尔·克雷格（Daniel Craig）时代是一个出色的形式回归。没有其他电影专营权。最接近的任务是不可能的，但是在我看来，该专营权是遥远的第二名。 It lacks a certain magic, a timeless but yet somehow always modern je ne sais quoi of the 007 franchise. Always the same, but somehow always fresh.

I expect Amazon to bleed it dry, alas. Spinoffs and “universe” expansion galore, of generally low quality in all regards: writing, casting, production values. But most of all I expect they'll make the same fundamental mistake Disney has made with Star Wars — instead of leaving us craving more, they'll produce as much dreck as they can and leave us saying “ enough, stop ”, with the occasional gems fighting for attention in a river of downright embarrassing unwatchable crap . Somehow they managed to ruin Boba Fett.

What's the best original show or movie Amazon has ever made? The Peripheral was pretty good but they cancelled after its first season. Reacher is fun but it's junk-food fun, not serious fun. Amazon taking control of James Bond is like McDonald's taking over a great steakhouse chain like Del Frisco's .

我对此有一种不好的感觉。

★

entry.summary: The iPhone 16e is arguably just plain a better phone than the iPhone 15, and I think it's almost inarguably a better value at $100 less.
entry.content:
Last week Tim Cook teased a “newest member of the family” product announcement coming today; turns out it was the iPhone 16e , a device whose name briefly paralyzed me with indecision regarding how to capitalize it, 1 which replaces the three-year-old iPhone SE (3rd generation) in the lineup.

The Announcement

Apple made the announcement in a 13-minute video that is currently atop their home page, but seemingly only perma-linkable at YouTube . (Maybe this ?) It was also, of course, announced in a press release on Apple Newsroom . The first three minutes of the video feature Tim Cook (talking about how great iPhones are, the iPhones 16 in particular, and Apple Intelligence). Cook hands things off to iPhone product marketing VP Kaiann Drance for the next five minutes; Drance mostly recaps iOS 18's tentpole features, especially, of course, Apple Intelligence. Drance hands off to keynote first-timer (I think) Lucy Browning, a director of iPhone product design, who talks up the 16e specifics. The most unusual thing about the video is its setting: not Apple Park, not the Steve Jobs Theater, but the infinite white void , where, in a bygone era, Apple TV commercials like the famed Hodgman/Long “I'm a Mac / I'm a PC” series were set. (The new infinite void is arguably light gray, not white.)

The Name

First, the name. It's not the fourth-generation iPhone SE, and instead sports an altogether new “e” suffix. Apple has used an “S” suffix with the iPhones 4S, 5S, 6S, and XS; “C” with the iPhone 5C, and “R” with the XR. We shall see if this “e” is a one-off. In an online press briefing today, when asked whether the “e” stands for anything, an Apple rep said no, it does not stand for anything, but that it's built for everyone. I don't think she meant to imply that the “e” secretly stands for everyone , if only because I'm pretty sure Apple doesn't want everyone buying the lowest-price iPhone model. Apple never had an explanation for the “SE” name either, although in my head I've already read that as maybe sorta kinda standing for special edition ? Way back in the day, I think Phil Schiller once said the “S” in “iPhone 3GS” stood for speed , because the 3GS was in fact strikingly faster than the prior year's 3G, and the “C” in “iPhone 5C” definitely, if unofficially, stood for color . But it's best not to waste too much time trying to find any logic to this other than that Apple thinks “iPhone 16e” looks and sounds cool. I'm just glad it's not the “iPhone 16 AI”.

Using the “16” generation as part of the name is more interesting than the new “e” suffix. It perhaps suggests that e-edition phones might become annual. I wouldn't bet on that. But the SE models came out in March 2016, April 2020, and March 2022, so the gaps have been irregular. At the very least though, the 16e name will help make it clear, in years to come, what the basic specs of this iPhone were and when, roughly, it debuted. Every time I've referenced the third-gen SE in the last year or two, I've had to look up exactly when it debuted and which A-series chip it sported (A15, same as the iPhone 13).

定价

As expected, the existing third-gen iPhone SE is now out of the lineup. The third-gen SE debuted in March 2022 with a starting price of $430 (for a paltry 64 GB) with 128 and 256 GB configurations for, respectively, $480 and $580. The new iPhone 16e starts at $600, which, depending on how you look at it, is either a $170 increase (in the price of the cheapest new iPhone Apple sells) or a $120 increase (in the price of the cheapest 128 GB iPhone Apple sells). I've already seen gobs of people arguing that the iPhone 16e “should” start at just $500, but if you look at Apple's pricing for the entire iPhone 16 lineup, there are $200 gaps, for the same storage tiers, between the 16e and regular 16, and between the regular 16 and 16 Pro. So I'd argue that $600 is the “right” price. It's also worth pointing out that, according to the US Bureau of Labor Statistics's inflation calculator , $500 in January 2022 is about $565 in January 2025 dollars.

Here's a table with the lineup of new iPhones Apple currently sells. I'm including the now-discontinued iPhone SE for reference. Also note that while these are the only models Apple itself sells to consumers, other old models are still sold by various carriers and retail partners around the world, including the iPhone SE for now.

芯片64 GB 128 GB 256 GB 512 GB 1 TB
iPhone SE A15 $430 $480 $ 580 - -
iPhone 16e A18 - $ 600 $700 $ 900 -
iPhone 15 A16 - $700 $800 $ 1,000 -
iPhone 16 A18 - $800 $ 900 $1,100 -
iPhone 16 Pro A18 Pro - $ 1,000 $1,100 $1,300 $ 1,500

iPhone 16 Plus and 16 Pro Max cost $100 more than their regular-size siblings.
iPhone 16 Pro Max is not available with 128 GB, and thus starts at $1,200.

Key differences in the iPhone 16e from the regular iPhone 16 (and iPhone 15), roughly in order of interest, or at least interestingness, to me:

No MagSafe

I find this a surprising omission. The 16e does support inductive Qi charging, but only at a pokey 7.5-watt rate. The regular 16 and 16 Pro models support MagSafe charging at up to 25 watts, and the iPhone 15 at 15 watts. You can charge an iPhone 16e using a MagSafe charging puck, but only at 7.5 watts, and it won't magnetically snap into place. It'll just function as a non-magnetic pad. I don't know if this decision was about component pricing (the $200 difference has to come from somewhere, and it's not going to be Apple's margins), the internal space that MagSafe components occupy in the device (see next section), or marketing分化。 Probably some combination of all three. The old SE only supported 7.5-watt no-MagSafe Qi charging as well.

电池

Battery life is better than the regular iPhone 16. This is equally surprising to me. From Apple's own Comparison page:

How exactly is the 16e achieving battery life that surpasses the more expensive iPhone 16, and is effectively on par with the much more expensive iPhone 16 Pro? I suspect it's a combination of a larger battery and a more efficient cellular modem. As rumored, the 16e is Apple's first iPhone with an in-house–designed modem, which, in the video, Kaiann Drance introduces thus (emphasis added): “And with iPhone 16e, we're expanding the benefits of Apple silicon with C1, the first Apple-designed cellular modem. It provides fast and reliable 5G connectivity, and it's the most power-efficient modem ever in an iPhone .” Just as with CPUs and GPUs, Apple's interest in custom silicon isn't only about price and performance — it's about efficiency too. Drance then continues (speaking over a cool breakaway animation of the 16e's internal components), “We combined the incredible power efficiency of Apple silicon with an all-new internal design for iPhone 16e that has been optimized for a larger battery. Together, it paves the way for an unprecedented level of battery life in a 6.1-inch iPhone.” There might be other changes that allow the 16e to accommodate a larger battery than the regular 16, but from the spec sheet, the obvious one is the omission of MagSafe.

Apple's C1 Chip

The power efficiency sounds great, and of course the modem supports “5G”, but it doesn't support mmWave / ultra wideband, the crazy super-fast variant of 5G with Wi-Fi-like speed and Wi-Fi-like short range from carrier antennas that serve it. Block-by-block here at home in Philadelphia, I see ultra wideband from Verizon on some blocks of the city ( denoted by the “5G UW” icon in the status bar ), but not most. But do I really care? I honestly don't know why I'm supposed to care about 5G at all compared to LTE. Using LTE instead of 5G (let alone 5G ultra wideband) makes no practical difference for anything I do over cellular on my phone. Obviously Apple wants to support ultra wideband in its own modems eventually, but their renewed deal with Qualcomm — announced and crowed-about only by Qualcomm , because Apple despises them and deeply resents its own dependence upon them — covers “smartphone launches in 2024, 2025 and 2026”. So I don't think we'll see a C-series chip in this September's expected iPhone 17 or 17 Pro — but perhaps we'll see one in the rumored iPhone 17 “Air”.

Remember too that when last I saw it tested — by Nicole Nguyen in 2022 — disabling 5G and exclusively using LTE extended the battery life of an iPhone 13 Pro from 13 to 15.5 hours in her video-streaming test. Ultra wideband 5G is indeed insanely fast , and regular 5G is generally faster than LTE, but for most people in most places not in ways that practically matter, especially considering the effects on battery life. “Plenty fast enough, with longer battery life” is a better trade-off than “way faster than you'll notice, with somewhat shorter battery life”.

Speaking of wireless, I don't know if it's related to the C1 chip, but the iPhone 16e supports only Wi-Fi 6, not 7, and doesn't support Thread networking.

Just One Camera on the Back, but It's “2-in-1”

No surprise here — cameras are expensive, and only offering one makes for very obvious differentiation. Apple's calling this lone camera “2-in-1” because, like the main camera on other recent iPhone models, it offers both 1× and 2× optical fields of view (1× uses the entire 48MP sensor, producing a 12MP image by treating the sensor pixel array as “quad pixels; 2× produces 12MP images by cropping the center 12MP of the sensor). The lack of a second ultra-wide camera means not just no 0.5× lens, but also no macro photography, and no spatial photos or video. The 16e also offers only “Photographic Styles”, not the “latest-generation Photographic Styles” offered by the 16 and 16 Pro .

If you really care about your camera , the iPhone 16e isn't the iPhone for you. As mentioned above, it has fewer lenses and the imaging pipeline doesn't support the next-generation Photographic Styles (which, five months in, I continue to really enjoy in my own photography). But that doesn't mean the iPhone 16e isn't a valid choice for people who care about their photos. Some people really do care about their photography, but also really just point and shoot using their main 1× camera, no matter which iPhone model they own. Not worrying about camera hardware and only concerning yourself with lighting and framing is a philosophy shared by many seriously talented photographers.

No Camera Control Button

The other camera-hardware-related ding against the 16e is that it doesn't have the new Camera Control button/slider on the side. I know several iPhone 16 owners who claim they never use it or even flat out dislike it, because they find themselves invoking it only by accident. I really like it, and use it as my primary way to launch the Camera app and to capture images. But, you know, we all captured images and videos just fine for 17 iPhone generations without that hardware button. No matter how much you like it, you certainly don't need it.

But, up until now, you did need the Camera Control button to invoke the visual intelligence feature of Apple Intelligence . A press-and-release of Camera Control launches your favorite camera app; a long-press invokes visual intelligence. Apple's solution to enable visual intelligence on the iPhone 16e, despite it lacking the Camera Control button, is two-fold. First, visual intelligence is now available in Control Center. Second, as demonstrated by Apple in the announcement video, you can assign the Action Button to visual intelligence. (By default, just as with other iPhones equipped with the Action Button, it defaults to toggling silent mode, like the dedicated ringer switch of yore — where by “yore” I mean still on the iPhone 15.)

Apple representatives also told me today that owners of the iPhone 15 Pro will soon be able to bind their Action Button to visual intelligence, “in a future software update”. I suspect that future software update is iOS 18.4, which should be launching in beta any day now, but Apple wouldn't comment, on or off the record, when exactly this feature will come to the iPhone 15 Pro. They also confirmed that the Control Center button to launch visual intelligence is also coming to iPhone 15 Pro (and presumably iPhone 16 models, too). The iPhone 15 Pro, despite qualifying for Apple Intelligence, has heretofore lacked the visual intelligence feature, because the visual intelligence feature has only been trigger-able via the Camera Control button. It's a little odd, frankly, that Apple didn't enable this feature via the Action Button and Control Center for 15 Pro users months ago — perhaps they really wanted to wait for the 16e announcement?

展示

The 16e display specs seem pretty good, but the front sensor array is behind a notch, not a dynamic island. That's a reasonable design trade-off for the lowest-price model. The 16 and 16 Pro displays offer maximum brightness specs of 1,000 nits (typical), 1,600 nits (HDR), and 2,000 nits (outdoor). The 16e display offers 800 nits (typical), 1,200 (HDR), and doesn't go higher than that. The 16 and 16 Pro dislays also go down to just 1 nit minimum brightness; Apple doesn't list a minimum brightness for the 16e display.

硅

The A18 chip in the iPhone 16e seems (on the specs page) nearly identical to that of the iPhone 16, except for the number of GPU cores: the 16e has only 4 GPU cores, but the regular iPhone 16 has 5. (The A18 Pro chip in the iPhone 16 Pro/Pro Max has 6 GPU cores.) No big whoop.

What's more interesting than comparing to the iPhone 16 is comparing to the iPhone 15, which costs $100 more than the 16e. Because the only A17-generation chip was the A17 Pro that went into the iPhone 15 Pro models, the regular iPhone 15 has the same A16 chip from the iPhone 14 model year. Aside from all the general performance improvements in the A18 compared to the two-year-old A16, the big functional difference is that the iPhone 16e supports Apple Intelligence and the iPhone 15 does not. As covered extensively when Apple Intelligence was announced at WWDC last June, that's mainly a function of RAM, but whatever the reasons, the less expensive iPhone 16e has Apple Intelligence, and the iPhone 15 does not. Maybe that's not a big whoop, but it's definitely a whoop of some sort.

Perhaps, like the three generations of SE models, the iPhone 16e is designed to stay around for several years at this price point. If it does, the fact that it costs $100 less than the “year-old regular iPhone” will make more sense come September, when that $700 year-old model is the iPhone 16. But until September, the iPhone 16e looks like a better phone in several ways than the iPhone 15. It has a faster chip that supports Apple Intelligence and significantly longer battery life. The iPhone 15 does have a 0.5× ultra-wide camera, and it has a slightly better display (that includes the nicer dynamic island instead of a notch). And of course the iPhone 15 comes in colors like pink, yellow, green, and blue. But if you keep your phone in a case all the time, like most people do, you probably don't care about the color of your phone much. The iPhone 16e is arguably just plain a better phone than the iPhone 15, and I think it's almost inarguably a better value at $100 less.

颜色

You can get any color 16e that you want, so long as it's black or white. The third-gen iPhone SE came in midnight, starlight, and Product Red. (Is Apple done partnering with Product Red now? I think Apple Watch Series 9 was the last device offered with Product Red .)

  1. For a while with the iPhone 4S, there was some ambiguity whether Apple intended the “S” to be upper- or lowercase, because their marketing materials used a small-cap “S”, and a small-cap “S” looks almost exactly like a lowercase “s”. They settled on uppercase for the 4S. But when the iPhone 5S and 5C were released, Apple not only styled both of those suffixes lowercase, they retroactively re-styled the 'S' in the '4S' as lowercase. I wrote about this at length in this footnote in my iPhone 5S and 5C review in 2013 , in which I explained my decision to uppercase them. But I sort of like the way “16e” looks. It's ... friendly? And the lowercase “e” carries the correct implication that this is a lesser sibling to the regular iPhone 16, not an upgrade or superior of some sort. So for now, I'm going with the flow and keeping the “e” lowercase. One friend, to whom I vented my consternation regarding how to handle this, unhelpfully suggested I go with iPhone 16ᵉ . ↩︎

entry.title: When 'FAQ' Stands for 'Fucking Angry Questions'
entry.content:
From Humane's “AI Pin Consumers FAQ”, which they link to with one of the best euphemisms of the year thus far — “We understand this transition may be difficult, and you may have questions”:

Key Dates to Remember:

  • Effective immediately : Ai Pin is no longer available for new purchases.
  • February 28, 2025 at 12pm PST : Ai Pin devices will no longer connect to Humane's servers, and .Center access will be fully retired.
  • February 28, 2025 at 12pm PST : All customer data, including personal identifiable information (PII), will be permanently deleted from Humane's servers.

This was a $700 purchase (for the matte black base model — polished metal ones were $800) with a mandatory $24/month service charge (which included cellular networking) and extra battery “boosters” were $70. Customers who bought when it launched last April have spent at least $1,000, but probably more, all told. Humane gave them 10 days notice before the thing turns into a brick.

Will I receive a refund for my Ai Pin?

Refunds are only available for customers who are still within the 90-day return window from their original shipment date. You are eligible to receive a refund if your product shipped on or after November 15th, 2024. All device shipments prior to November 15th, 2024 are not eligible for refunds. All refunds must be submitted by February 27th, 2025.

Translation: tough shit.

Will my Ai Pin work with another cellular provider after the shutdown?

No. Once the service is discontinued, your Ai Pin will no longer function as a cellular device or connect to Humane's servers. This means no calls, texts, or data usage will be possible. [...]

Can I still use my Ai Pin for offline features?

是的。 After February 28, 2025, Ai Pin will still allow for offline features like battery level, etc., but will not include any function that requires cloud connectivity like voice interactions, AI responses, and .Center access.

You can check the battery of a device that no longer offers any useful functionality. I get it, companies go bust, and when they go bust, their services go bust with them. But this is exactly the sort of outcome that made Humane's AI Pin seem more like a scam than a product all along.

★

entry.title: We Found the Sucker Willing to Buy Humane, and as Promised, I'm Going to Be Insufferable, Because of Course It Was HP
entry.content:
Brody Ford, reporting for Bloomberg:

HP Inc. will acquire assets from Humane Inc., the maker of a wearable Ai Pin introduced in late 2023, for $116 million.

The deal will include the majority of Humane's employees in addition to its software platform and intellectual property, the company said Tuesday. It will not include Humane's Ai pin device business, which will be wound down, an HP spokesperson said.

Humane's team, including founders Imran Chaudhri and Bethany Bongiorno, will form a new division at HP to help integrate artificial intelligence into the company's personal computers, printers and connected conference rooms, said Tuan Tran, who leads HP's AI initiatives. Chaudhri and Bongiorno were design and software engineers at Apple Inc. before founding the startup.

Yours truly, last May , when news broke that Humane was looking for a buyer, “seeking a price of between $750 million and $1 billion in a sale”:

I suspect they'll sell for a pittance — way less than the $230 million they've raised. I just don't see what they have to offer. Humane doesn't own the AI that powers the AI Pin — that comes from OpenAI, which seemingly not only doesn't want to buy Humane, but is supposedly in exploratory talks with Jony Ive's LoveFrom to design and build their own AI devices. The laser projector idea seems to be a bust, and the hardware's battery life is measured in hours between battery pack swaps.

Off the top of my head, the only company that could afford a $1 billion-ish price for Humane and is dumb enough to do it is HP.

Well, at least we can say HP was smart enough not to spend $1 billion on this. But they were dumb enough to bring into their company Chaudhri, who was described to me, by someone who worked with him at Apple (and a person whom I've never heard badmouth a single other former colleague), as “an utter fraud” 。 But a fraud whose personal website is an inadvertent testimony to the lunacy of the US patent system — that it serves ego inflation, not innovation.

但是谁知道？ Maybe I'm all wet and Humane will prove to HP what NeXT proved to Apple, and we'll all be hanging on every thread of Imran Chaudhri keynotes in a few years and he'll lead HP back to greatness. (Almost laughed spittle onto my screen there.)

★

entry.summary: Much serious thought and consideration, from very smart people in Mountain View and Cupertino, went into determining how to respond to a profoundly silly and thoughtless executive order. Yet that response is disturbing.
entry.content:
You saw the news last week, I'm sure, that both of the major mapping-app providers, Google and Apple, have updated their maps to refer to the Gulf of Mexico as the “Gulf of America” . Microsoft's Bing Maps, which I would describe as a minor provider, has made the change too. 1 It's all actually quite a bit more complicated than “they renamed the Gulf of Mexico”, but bear with me for now.

You've also seen, I'm equally sure, a lot of people angry at Google and Apple for going along with this. That anger is — to some degree — misplaced. I get where the anger comes from, but it's still misplaced. My initial take, right in the midst of Trump's inauguration speech on January 20, was that if he went through with it, Apple and Google and everyone else who publishes maps should just ignore it. Trump, obviously, did go through with it: the United States Geological Survey, an agency within the Department of the Interior, which is within the executive branch and thus under the president's purview, officially made the change on February 7 . Now that it's official US government policy, “just ignore it” really isn't feasible. If that's still your stance, I implore you to consider at least a bit more nuance.

But let's first stipulate up front that there are multiple far more important and urgent issues facing the United States and the world, just four short weeks into the Trump 2.0 administration. Off the top of my head: Ukraine, Gaza, tariffs, DOGE, the rule of law . Whether you approve or disapprove of Trump's actions on any or all of those issues, there should be no question that all of them are important and consequential. The name we see on maps for a body of water, not as much. But it's the smallness, the relative unimportance, the spiteful pettiness of the renaming in the first place — down to the fact that until Trump's executive action, there was no controversy, zero , none , nada , anywhere in the world, amongst any group of people, regarding the name of the Gulf of Mexico — that makes it interesting to examine in detail how Google and Apple have chosen to deal with it. It's only because this particular issue is so spectacularly piddling that we can consider it in full.

The motivation behind the name change is simple as well. Trump didn't change the US's officially recognized name of, say, the Atlantic Ocean or the continent of Africa. He just as easily could, but he won't. And it's not like “Gulf of Mexico” was on a list of “debatable or controversial names” until he created this controversy out of thin air. It's just the one name on the globe that a president of the United States can change to stick it to Mexico, a country Donald Trump has objectively racist feelings toward . Trump never campaigned on building a wall at our northern border with Canada, nor has he (yet?) attempted to rename Lake Ontario. It's about Mexico, and asserting power by fiat. Trump has a lifelong history of putting his name on buildings he doesn't own . He'd rather have his name emblazoned on a building he doesn't own than own a building that doesn't bear his name. To Trump, the name on the sign is more important than the deed. So too, now, with the name on a map. The Gulf of Mexico is an international body of water that belongs to no nation, but declaring this new name implies that it heretofore belonged to Mexico, and now belongs to us, which is to say belongs to him, our unquestioned dear leader. That Trump took it from Mexico, without firing a shot — when in fact all he did was order a string to be changed in a government database. Shakespeare would have us believe that a sea by any other name would taste as salty. Trump doesn't read Shakespeare.

How Google and Apple Are Labelling the Gulf, Globally

The first important thing to know is that Google Maps and Apple Maps are not singular global atlases. They both show different names (and in rare cases, different geographies) in different regions around the world. They each are more like a collection of regional atlases. In constrast, there's only one Oxford English Dictionary . If the OED changes a word's definition, or adds a new word, those changes appear to everyone in the world. My OED is your OED, no matter where you and I live or currently find ourselves on the globe. Google and Apple Maps aren't like that. It's better to think of them as services that provide region-by-region maps.

Google, to their credit, has a blog post describing and illustrating exactly what users around the world now see in Google Maps :

In the US, the Geographic Names Information System (GNIS) has officially updated “Gulf of Mexico” to “Gulf of America.” As we announced two weeks ago and consistent with our longstanding practices, we've begun rolling out changes to reflect this update. People using Maps in the US will see “Gulf of America,” and people in Mexico will see “Gulf of Mexico.” Everyone else will see both names.

As their illustration shows , “both names” means putting “Gulf of America” in parentheses for users who are anywhere else in the world other than the US or Mexico: “Gulf of Mexico (Gulf of America)”.

Apple's approach has been more Apple-like, which is to say without comment. They made no public comment before changing the name in Apple Maps, and they have made no public comment since. (I've asked Apple PR for comment, but gotten none.) I'd appreciate a statement, like Google's, stating what users around the world should expect to see. But I also understand their desire to say as little as possible. In a sense, the labels on Apple Maps speak for themselves, and are the only thing that actually matters. I also appreciate, that by never declaring a policy on the matter, Apple can change its map labels without rescinding or amending a policy.

So without a statement from Apple describing how the Gulf is labelled around the world, I did what I could: I asked my followers on Mastodon who are outside the US what they saw as the Gulf's name , and to include screenshots if possible. That was on Friday, 14 February, after Apple Maps began showing “Gulf of America” in place of “Gulf of Mexico” to users here in the US. The response was overwhelming, with replies from people in over two dozen countries from around the world. 2 And at the time, their replies suggested that Apple was taking a subtly but intriguingly different approach from Google.机智，虽然美国每个人都看到“美国湾”（没有提及既定名称），但世界上其他所有人仍然看到“墨西哥湾”（或他们的语言对该名称的翻译），但没有提及在括号或其他情况下，美国现在认可的新名称。

我希望那是苹果的计划，在将美国隔离为世界上唯一一个名字“美国湾”这个名字时，它会悄悄地颠覆。但是我担心苹果只是比Google慢的，它首先是为美国用户应用的，但是世界其他地区的变化根本没有传播。我的恐惧是有必要的。

傍晚（美国东部时间）2月15日（美国东部时间），对我对Mastodon的恳求的新回应开始在与Google的苹果地图上展示标签：

  • 在美国：“美国湾”。
  • 在墨西哥：“墨西哥湾”。
  • 其他地方：“墨西哥湾（美国海湾）”。

我相信，您看到的标签的决定因素，至少在Apple地图上，与您的物理位置无关，如GPS或IP地址所确定的，而仅仅是OS的区域设置。在MacOS和iOS上，这是在设置→常规→语言和区域→区域中。这很有意义 - 您可以使用Apple Map（和Google Maps）使用位置服务关闭。您可以在设备上使用此设置，以查看世界各地的用户在地图中看到什么而无需离开家，而无需更改设备的语言。因此，如果您是一个设备设置为“美国”地区的美国人，如果您在美国外面旅行而不更改设备设置，您仍然会看到墨西哥湾的特定新名称：美国”，以其历史悠久的世界认可的名字 - 我敢说，它的明确正确的名字 - 甚至在括号中都没有引用。

依赖成人内衣的一年

不用说，这件事很糟糕。这是非常愚蠢的，而不是愚蠢的方面是jingoistic的。但是，Google或Apple可能会合理地忽略这一点的观念，并告诉特朗普（以及整个共和党及其支持者）跌倒沙子。我并不是说他们做不到。当然可以。这就像说特朗普不能仅仅宣布以迄今为止无争议的400年历史的国际水域的新名字。

但这是不合理的。 Google和Apple地图可以延期或至少确认其可用区域的正式认可名称是合理的。确定和裁定地图上的官方名称不是Google或Apple的位置；他们的工作是识别并显示这些名称。从理论上讲，Google和/或Apple可以将自己定位为地理名称的全球权威参考。要映射类似于OED或Merriam-Webster的东西，以映射到英语。但是，如果他们追求那条路线，他们就会将自己置于裁决任何和所有争议和边界的争议和争议。公民政府是我们应该希望进行此类争议仲裁的地方，即使没有解决。不是由私人公司。如果苹果地图在中国可用，那么苹果地图就需要呈现姓名和边界（ 甚至是土地群体的规模，在下面更多），这是中国政府可容纳的。中国之所以坚持下去，是因为他们的要求与世界其他地区认可的名称和边界形成鲜明对比。中国地图由CCP规定的教条支配。大多数地图受地理和地缘政治现实的约束。例如，台湾实际上是一个独立的国家。中国地图（包括苹果公司为中国大陆用户服务的地图）将台湾标记为中国省。

现在，美国受到另一种教条驱动政权的约束。

entry.title: How WikiTok Was Created

Wikitok的最初想法起源于周一晚上的开发人员Tyler Angert，当时他在推文中说：“疯狂的项目创意：Wikipedia的所有Wikipedia都在一个可滚动的页面上。”彭博beta beta vc詹姆斯·康（James Cham）回答：“更好，一个基于您接下来感兴趣的任何内容？”在后续帖子中，Angert创造了“ Wikitok”。

第二天清晨，凌晨12:28，作家格兰特·斯拉顿（Grant Slatton）引用了维基托克（Wikitok）的讨论，这就是Gemal的来源。 “我立即想到，'哇，我可以建造一个MVP（最低可行的产品），这可能会起飞。'”

Gemal于上午12:30启动了他的项目，并在AI编码工具（如Anthropic's Claude and Cursor ）的帮助下，他在凌晨2点之前完成了原型。该网站的每日新闻列表。

“整个事情只有数百行代码，克劳德（Claude）写下了绝大多数的代码，”杰尔（Gemal）告诉ARS。 “ AI帮助我的运输非常快，只是利用了最初的病毒推文，要求Wikipedia滚动。”

起初，我读到该项目从中午到凌晨2点开始推出，我给我留下了深刻的印象。然后，我重新阅读了它，意识到只有90分钟。吉米尼。通过AI协助进行编程只是傻瓜。

entry.title: Wikitok - 带有Tiktok风格的界面的Web应用程序，用于探索随机Wikipedia文章
entry.content:
Wikitok是Isaac Gemal的创建。前提是，这是Wikipedia随机文章的Tiktok风格界面。一件事一次在屏幕上，在准备就绪时向下滑动以向下滚动到下一个物品，如果需要，您可以永远继续前进。但是，这些是事实，而不是倾向于无意识的媒体热卡路里的视频。 Wikitok根本没有视频 - 每个项目只是全出来的图像，也是一个摘要的事实。 （当然，还有一个“阅读更多”链接，可以在新的浏览器选项卡中打开Wikipedia的完整条目。）它不会在订婚时击败实际的Tiktok，但Tiktok无法击败Wikitok的精神滋养。这就像选择在不是垃圾的东西上零食。

Wikitok在任何尺寸的设备上都可以使用，但是像Tiktok一样，它显然是在手机上使用的。将其保存到主屏幕上，就像拥有应用程序一样。在NFL赛季和March Madness（在那之后，棒球之后）之间的这个中期期间，我从Apple Sports的第一个主屏幕上释放了一个空间，目前，我将Wikitok放在那里。我不知道它会持续多久。实际上我感兴趣的事情的“命中率”有点低 - 但也许这就是Tiktok本身的样子？而且，每次启动它时，我都会在几次滑动中学习一些有趣的东西。没有算法可以为它显示的内容提供动力，但是我希望有 - 我会心跳转向一块Wikitok的叉子，这些Wikitok学习了，甚至只有一点，实际上是什么样的东西让我感兴趣。尝试一下。鉴于检查新闻的另一种经验，目前Wikitok的首次亮相似乎尤为恰当。

如果我只能弯曲Gemal的耳朵，我恳求他考虑将名字从Wikitok更改为Wiktok。那个不必要的中间音节引起了不一致的音符。说出您想要的Tiktok，但这是一个很棒的名字。在口头上， Wikitok听起来像Wikitalk ，听起来像Wikipedia编辑可能将每个条目称为Meta-Discussion“ Talk”页面。另一方面， Wiktok在视觉上和口头上都是与Tiktok平行的。

entry.title: 苹果的原始“互联网策略”，从2000年1月开始
entry.content:
从苹果新闻编辑室档案室，Dateline“旧金山麦克沃尔德博览会 - 2000年1月5日”：

苹果今天将其备受期待的互联网策略推出，引入了一种新的互联网服务，称为Itools。一个完全重新设计的Apple.com网站，其中包含IREVIEW和ICARDS；以及与Earthlink的多年合作伙伴关系和投资，用于互联网访问（请参阅相关版本）。

Itools是革命性的互联网服务新类别，它利用了Internet两端的苹果公司的独特技术 - 客户端的操作系统（MAC OS 9）和在Apple的Internet服务器（ITOOLS）上运行的服务软件。在Internet两端提供该软件为Apple提供了前所未有的能力，可以提供无法仅在Internet服务器上实施的服务。

苹果公司Iceo的史蒂夫·乔布斯（Steve Jobs）表示：“我们的新Ireview，Icards和革命性的ITools为Mac用户提供了令人惊叹的新方法，可以充分利用互联网。” “ Mac用户现在可以在Wintel用户只能梦想的互联网上做一些事情。”

事后看来，这令人震惊的是，苹果大约在2000年毫不掩饰地是笨拙的弱者。如果非常高度期待公告，您不必将其描述为“备受期待的”。乔布斯引用了包括口语的“ Wintel”。

从功能列表中：

Mac.com，由Apple运营的电子邮件服务。 Mac.com在Internet上为用户提供了一个独家地址，并与标准的POP电子邮件客户端一起使用，例如Outlook Express，Eudora和Netscape Communicator。 Mac.com用户可以轻松地设置自动答复，并将其电子邮件转发到其他电子邮件地址，并从简单的网页上为其Mac.com邮箱配置Outlook Express。

因此，我误解了我今天早些时候如何进入分叉的Apple帐户情况的时间表（但在那个帖子中我是正确的，以至于不确定时间表）。我的 @Mac.com地址确实早于iTunes音乐商店的首次亮相，但是自2000年1月宣布Itools以来，我已经宣布了Itools，而不是在2002年7月宣布的.mac（最糟糕的苹果名称？）。托马斯（Thomas）品牌提醒我。）品牌发展是：

itools （2000）→ .mac （2002）→ Mobileme （2008）→ iCloud （2011）

苹果花了十年的时间才从itools到iCloud，但iCloud被证明是赢家。 It's interesting to think of the “Internet moment” circa 2000 compared to the “AI moment” today.大约2000年，热门的新公司没有制作计算机或设备，也没有制作在消费设备上运行的软件。 They made websites and web apps that ran in browsers on devices.

然后，针对苹果的熊案是，他们错过了大事物上的船，他们的核心优势不再具有意义。现在几乎相同的熊盒：AI。不同之处在于，今天的苹果不仅不是“笨拙的弱者”，而且是世界上最有价值的公司。

entry.summary: 不同并不总是意味着更好。但更好的是一定意味着不同的。
entry.content:
Scorebug是Chyron （本身术语）子类型的行业术语，它在您观看时显示了有关电视转播的体育赛事的信息。这些图形显示了与当前情况有关的团队，得分，剩余时间和其他元数据。当前的球/击球数在棒球中。足球的下降和码头。篮球中的射门钟。那种事情。 1

福克斯（Fox）昨天是超级碗59号的广播网络，费城老鹰队（Filadelphia Eagles）完全使堪萨斯城酋长40-22感到尴尬（但感觉像是114-0的得分）。 NFL每年在广播游戏的网络之间旋转超级碗。福克斯（Fox）拥有超级碗（Super Bowl）时发布更新屏幕图形包装的传统。今年，他们不仅调整了设计，还完全重新考虑了设计并重新设计了它。

首先，这是福克斯（Fox）熟悉的老得分杯，从他们的超级碗57号广播中捕获了这场比赛，这一游戏也使老鹰队与酋长队在两年前与酋长队相处融洽。 2

这是他们昨晚在今年最大的体育观众面前首次亮相的新Scorebug：

我立即注意到（当然），我的膝盖即时反应是负面的。太大，太大了，太大了。不喜欢。那很自然。人类演变为被变革所震惊。如果一切看起来都和往常一样，那么一切都可能像往常一样安全。如果某种东西看起来差异很大，那可能是您即将被杀死的标志。 （从进化上讲。）

因此，我开始研究并考虑Fox得分刺的变化。我不仅很快就加入了新的Scorebug，还决定我真的很喜欢。它比福克斯的旧网络好，比其他每个网络都更好（在几乎每一个方面看起来都一样）。

我（Cross-）在游戏期间非常喜欢新的Scorebug。我的帖子按参与顺序：线程（〜6,600个赞，〜700个回复和重新发布），蓝调（〜3,900个赞，〜600个回复和转换）和mastodon （179个赞，53个回复和reposts）。

与更改应用程序的图标相比，应用程序开发人员可以做出的任何更改都不会产生用户更多的评论和情感反馈。每个人都看到了应用程序的图标，并且对它们有意见。经过改变后，这种观点通常是“我喜欢旧的图标，讨厌新的图标。同样，随着游戏广播的得分刺激 - 每个人都看到了它们，并且每个人都会改变时都有意见。对福克斯的新得分捕食的大多数反应都是负面的，其中许多反应确实是负面的。 Yahoo Sports ran a story under the headline “ Super Bowl: Fox Sports Debuts New Scorebug, to Universally Negative Reaction ”.以体育媒体为中心的网站糟糕地宣布了德鲁·勒纳（Drew Lerner）在标题下的“ 请在超级碗期间首次亮相新的得分俱乐部”（副标题：“我不能只看一个超级碗而不必学习新图形吗？” ）。我什至没有接近阅读我社交媒体的所有答复（嗯，除了在Mastodon上 - 很快就可以赶上那里），但是如果您仔细阅读它们，您会很快看到大多数答复来自鄙视变化的人。代表品尝：

“看起来好像他们只是让实习生在PowerPoint中敲一些东西，而没有打扰有人先检查一下。可怕。 👎”

“哈哈。因成为笨蛋而被静音。透明

“它很丑陋，其霸道的尺寸分散了游戏的实际内容。透明

“得分戒指绝对可怕！我真的希望他们不会在2025赛季采用这种情况，否则我会骚乱。可怕的设计，特别是分散注意力的乐谱，这看起来像是Fortnite的东西。透明

“看起来像是Fortnite的东西”并不是最后的评论者认为这是的。很多人玩耍和爱Fortnite。

这是一个扩展的（从我发布的内容到社交媒体），我喜欢新的Scorebug，也许甚至是爱。首先，主要项目：谁在玩游戏，得分是什么：

  • 团队初始主义：巨大。
  • 团队徽标：无。颜色足够说。
  • 得分：巨大。
  • 游戏时钟：足够大且居中。
  • 不必要的铬：无。

球迷们以2个或3个字母的缩写对联盟中的每个团队都熟悉，就像机场代码或股票股票一样。它们都是显而易见的（ 与许多机场代码不同）。达拉斯牛仔队是达尔。新英格兰爱国者是东北。对于拥有纽约和洛杉矶两个团队的两个城市，这些城市便利地缩写为两个字母，并从团队的昵称中汲取了第三个字母：巨人和喷气机是NYG和NYJ；公羊和充电器是lar和lac。

团队徽标并不能立即识别，尤其是在小尺寸的情况下。一群团队有愤怒的鸟摩托车：鹰，海鹰，猎鹰和红衣主教。您还记得田纳西泰坦的徽标吗？还是休斯顿德克萨斯人？克利夫兰布朗甚至没有徽标可以说。 （而且它们也不是棕色。）但是我保证您知道哪些球队是十，侯和CLE。 3

而且，重要的是，这些团队的初始主义并非仅由排版来代表：它们在带有团队的主要色彩的盒子里。与团队徽标相比，这种颜色的使用可实现所有品牌的工作，并以远距离的尺寸或从远距离查看更有效地做到这一点。 （我拥有的一个小麻烦是团队的初始主义是大白色的字母，但由团队的次要颜色概述。如果您仔细观察上面昨天的超级碗的屏幕截图，您会发现“ KC”在黄色上概述了“ phi”中的phi在正常的观看距离上具有效果，使初始主义看起来有些模糊。相反，团队具有使文字在屏幕上呈现不佳的意想不到的效果。

消除所有不必要的镀铬可以说是最引人注目的变化，因为福克斯的旧得分捕食最多具有最多的“ 3D”样式和纹理。 This isn't minimalism, per se, but it's a strike against needless decoration — reminiscent to my mind of Jony Ive's radical redesign of iOS 7 a decade ago.单独通过类型和颜色传达的元素仅通过类型和颜色表示。

其他值得注意的功能：

  • 剩下的超时：突出但不会分散注意力。看到一支球队剩下的超时是福克斯的旧得分捕食和大多数其他网络当前的得分cugs的巨大问题。 （在近距离足球比赛中剩下的超时非常重要。）

  • 当前的下降和码来指示指标（例如“ 1st＆10”） ：在团队初始主义顶部的位置传达了哪个球队拥有球。福克斯（Fox）的旧得分俱乐部确实有一个“拥有”指标，但是滚动回头查看它，看看您需要多长时间才能弄清楚它是什么。我将答案放在脚注中。 4

  • 排版：经典，清晰，大胆，永恒。它也非常“狐狸” - “ kc”中的c在经典的“福克斯”文字中看起来像o，而零（数字酋长球迷一直非常熟悉到第三季度的最后一秒钟，因为这就是方式直到那时，他们得分的许多积分 - 老鹰队在以34-0领先的途中骑自行车骑行了一堆不同的数字）几乎就像“福克斯”中的大写O。

更大，更大胆的版式增加了清晰度。但是，删除背景镀铬使观众可以“浏览”到屏幕底部发生的任何游戏动作。对我来说，只有一场比赛，旧的福克斯得分布格看上去毫无希望地过时了。老式没有任何怀旧魅力。如果有的话，新的排版优先设计是看起来永恒的设计，对经典NFL电影制作中的图形令人回味。

这是什么。 NFL广播并不总是有分数。我并不是说他们在屏幕上的得分指标较小。我的意思是他们根本没有。对于电视上的所有主要运动，不仅仅是足球比赛（例如，摩天比利斯（Ferris Bueller）休息日的插科打of）都是如此。直到1994年，这些网络将显示出削减商业休息时的分数和时间，然后在广告中回来时再次展示。但是，在比赛中，屏幕上没有得分。其中的一部分是技术：游戏电视转播是从房间各地看到的相对较小的电视屏幕的低空透射。回去足够远，甚至没有颜色。但是更大的方面是惯性。始终没有显示分数的方式是游戏总是广播的方式，所以这是他们仍然被广播的方式。

然后是福克斯。

几十年来，美国有三个主要的电视网络：ABC，NBC和CBS。哥伦比亚广播公司拥有高级国家橄榄球会议的周日比赛权利。 “高级”出于团队知名度和团队市场规模的相关原因，这对于评分很重要。芝加哥，费城，华盛顿，达拉斯，弗里斯科。 NBC拥有来自通常较小城市的球队的美国足球会议的周日比赛权利。堪萨斯城匹兹堡，迈阿密。好的团队，但是小城市。 （不过，在1993年，NFC球队连续9次赢得了9个超级碗。）

鲁珀特·默多克（Rupert Murdoch）的福克斯网络（Fox Network）试图建立第四个美国网络，很快就经历了足够的成功。在1987年首次亮相时，福克斯（Fox）在一周的一个晚上（周日，方便）只有黄金时段编程。 1993年，默多克和福克斯（Murdoch）和福克斯（Fox）通过超越（愚蠢的，紧身，狂热，狂热）的哥伦比亚广播公司（CBS）宣传体育广播的世界，以便在周日播放NFC游戏的权利。

2018年，布莱恩·柯蒂斯（Bryan Curtis）在林格（Ringer）出版了该交易的全面口述历史及其后果：“ 伟大的NFL抢劫：福克斯如何为足球付出和改变足球”。如果您完全感兴趣，请阅读。讲得很好，这是一个很棒的故事。

但是在1994年，福克斯接管了NFC广播。他们从哥伦比亚广播公司（CBS）偷猎了所有播音员，摄影师，导演和制片人。 （CBS不再需要它们，因为他们没有足球比赛可以广播。）但是，宣布该游戏的声音很熟悉（包括有史以来最好的二人组：John Madden和Pat Summerall），但外观和感觉广播有意新鲜，新鲜，而且因为是福克斯（Fox），布拉什（Brash）。这包括他们称为“狐狸盒”的创新。引用柯蒂斯在铃声中的口述历史：

戴维·希尔（David Hill）关于NFL的最具争议的想法是他最简单的：他认为分数和时钟应该在屏幕上有一个永久的房屋 - 该功能被称为“狐狸盒”。一群嘈杂的批评家和竞争对手的高管认为狐狸盒是一个可怕的主意。它会使屏幕混乱，并使人们摆脱井喷。但是希尔被说服了，因为他在一个令人沮丧的下午看着英国的足球后创建了一个原始的福克斯盒子

希尔：我们一直在walking狗。我们会进来，喝一杯茶，然后打开BBC。我看了15分钟的比赛。我不知道分数是多少。我对自己想：“该死，我真的很想知道分数是多少。”所以我想：“这很容易。在chyron上，我只是把它放在拐角处。”所以我做到了。

Madden：没有说：“不，这是一个愚蠢的主意，我们还有其他事情要做，”他说，“如果分数和时间是最重要的事情，我们为什么不把它放起来，然后leave it there?”那是狐狸盒的来源。那是大卫·希尔。

多尔金：所有网络都告诉我们：“您正在搞砸。你是白痴要这样做。”

阿尔伯特（Albert）：这个想法是，有些网络不会离开时间并得分，因为这是一场井喷，他们不希望您知道这是一场井喷。

“福克斯盒”的想法不仅有争议，而且被广泛愚蠢。网络从字面上认为，如果许多观众不知道分数会更好。当狐狸盒出现时，许多批评家都同意。这是丹·考克斯（Dan Cox）在1994年9月对福克斯（Fox）开幕周广播的评论：

该网络还坚持在几乎整个游戏中，在屏幕左上角都在屏幕上左上角的那个烦人的透明时钟和得分图形。 Fox Sports Prexy David Hill表示，重要的是要知道得分以及坐下来坐下时还剩多少时间。

好吧，是的。但是，那些实际观看游戏开始并宁愿让屏幕远离图形的人怎么样。

谁现在看起来很愚蠢？想象一下，如果福克斯（Fox）播出了昨天的超级碗（Super Bowl），那就想象一下，因为那些宁愿避开屏幕的人，否则昨天的超级碗都没有任何得分刺。

任何形式的变化总是会引起警报，无论它实际上是否更好。 30年前，当吸烟禁令开始在城市生效时，人们大声声称这将使餐馆，尤其是酒吧倒闭。吸烟者想吸烟，如果不能的话，就会待在家里。事实证明，如果您迫使吸烟者在寒冷的寒冷甚至雨中抽烟，他们会这样做。许多其他人（因为他们鄙视香烟的恶臭而呆在家里）开始更频繁地出去。事后看来，禁止共享公共场所的香烟（飞机，用于Chrissake！）显然是正确的决定。但是，不管有多明显，变化都是很难接受的。

我说福克斯的新得分蛋糕更好，并提出了骚动，只是因为它更好，以至于大多数观众注意到的只是它如此不同。当您习惯它时，您会看到。这种新设计具有更大的大胆类型，但不必要的镀铬，在最大的大屏幕上以更加清晰的方式传达了重要的壮举，这是在大型屏幕上 - 酒吧和餐馆等公共场所中的电视，从远处看，最小的小屏幕，我们的电话。

不同并不总是意味着更好。但更好的是一定意味着不同的。

  1. 您知道当您观看大多数电视频道时（不仅是运动，而且还没有表演）时，他们如何在屏幕的一个角落保留频道的徽标？这些无所不在的徽标称为错误（也许是因为每个人都知道它们有点烦人吗？）。因此：始终出现的得分指标的得分例。 ↩︎︎

  2. DF风格指南没有“罗马数字”的条目，因为没有足够强大的淫秽或专有人可以传达政策。 ↩︎︎

  3. 该设计可能不太有用的一场对决是Rams-Chargers游戏，因为除了共享城市（和体育场）外，它们甚至共享相同的团队颜色：蓝色和黄色。在两个相同颜色的盒子中的Lar和Lac并没有太大的清晰度。我很好奇福克斯（Fox）会播放这场比赛，该如何处理。这是可以解决的 -以下是一些示例，其中包括英超联赛的类似得分捕捞剂的不同颜色处理。也许其中一支团队会收到黄色的字母，另一个团队会收到黄色的字母。甚至是带有蓝色字母的黄色背景。 ↩︎︎

  4. 这是高于进攻球队得分之上的白色条。在2023年超级碗的上方屏幕捕获中，这就是老鹰队。这在视觉上是如此微妙和不直觉，以至于无疑是一个糟糕的设计。 ↩︎︎

entry.summary: My favorite (and least favorite) ads from Super Bowl 59.
entry.content:
Well, the Philadelphia Eagles, of course, won the actual Super Bowl, winning in a romp so one-sided that they would have embarrassed the Chiefs less if they had pantsed Patrick Mahomes at the 50-yard line. But the second contest is for best commercial. And my vote goes to Nike .

The problem with modern Super Bowl commercials is they're bland. Offensively bland. It really makes no sense to me. The commercial time is famously expensive — Fox was supposedly selling 30-second spots for last night's game for $8 million — but the sponsors who buy that time tend to squander it with absolute mindless pap.

Fewer and fewer sponsors each year, it seems, attempt to bring something actually interesting. Something different. Something with some punch. Something that's actually funny. Something that makes you actually feel . You don't have to make a genuinely artistic short film, like Apple's Ridley-Scott-directed 1984 spot heralding the introduction of the Macintosh — the ad that is justifiably regarded as the best commercial ever made. Some of what I'd list among the best Super Bowl ads ever were silly gimmicks that revelled in their abject silliness, like the “Bud Bowl” commercials (featuring anthropomorphic bottles of Budweiser and Bud Light playing football) — very far from “high art” but very fun, and created specifically to be shown once and only once, in the context of the Super Bowl. One simple measure is whether the ads are memorable. Most of the ads in last night's game I forgot by the time the game resumed after the break.

I don't know why anyone would book and commission a Super Bowl commercial if they weren't trying to do something or say something memorable with the spot. Still, though, there are always at least a handful of standouts.

My favorite yesterday was Nike's “So Win” spot , a heralding of its own — not for a new Nike product, but for the explosion in interest in women's sports, featuring WNBA phenom Caitlin Clark and a few other top women's athletes. Gorgeous black and white cinematography. Led Zeppelin's rollicking “ Whole Lotta Love ” as the soundtrack. And a righteous manifesto of a message, delivered with pitch-perfect gusto by narrator Doechii. Nike, it turns out , hadn't run a Super Bowl ad since 1998, and they came back with a banger that to me reinvigorated the Nike brand. They've been in a bit of a free fall and I think this ad was intended as much to inspire Nike employees as it was to female athletes and sports fans. (Shades of Apple's “Think Different” campaign.) I've re-watched this spot a few times while writing this post and I like it more each time.

荣誉提及：

  • ChatGPT's branding spot , positioning AI alongside historical breakthroughs in technology.喜欢它。 I think it was supposed to be a mystery until the very end of the 60-second spot who the ad was for and what exactly it was about, but I guessed “ChatGPT” about 5 seconds in. I kind of hate making a third comparison to an old Apple ad, but ChatGPT's spot does evoke — not as a rip-off, but homage — the 90-second “There are a thousand no's for every yes” opening film from WWDC 2013 , perhaps the nadir of Apple's post-Steve-Jobs grief.
  • Stella Artois : David Beckham learns that he has a twin brother, named Other David Beckham, whom his parents abandoned at birth in America. Beckham sets off to meet him. Don't read anything more about it, just watch. Good kicker at the end, too.

Dishonorable mention:

  • Tubi is a streaming platform owned by Fox. Apparently it's existed since 2014 and has been owned by Fox since 2020, but I'd forgotten it existed until this week, when it was in the news as the streaming platform carrying the Super Bowl. Fox ran a couple of house ads, intended to promote Tubi, about a young man born with a head shaped like a cowboy hat . Memorable, yes, but the execution was revolting, not funny. The message I took was that Tubi is the streaming app that will make you feel grossed out.

entry.summary: While there are several areas where Apple maintained consistent excellence in 2024, I can't think of a single area where Apple levelled up.不是一个。 That feels like a problem.
entry.content:
This week Jason Snell published his annual Six Colors Apple Report Card for 2024 . As I've done in the past — 2023 , 2022 , 2021 , 2020 , 2019 , 2018 — I'm publishing my full remarks and grades here. On Snell's report card, voters give per-category scores ranging from 5 to 1; I've translated these to letter grades, A to F, which is how I consider them. 1

Most of my grades are unchanged from a year ago. For those that have changed, I've noted last year's grade in parentheses. I didn't realize this as I was writing my report card, but each of my grades that changed from last year went lower . Not one grade went up. Thinking about that as I write this preamble today, it feels correct: there are several areas where Apple maintained consistent excellence in 2024, but I can't think of a single area where Apple levelled up.不是一个。 That feels like a problem. 2

It's also worth noting that “Siri” is not a standalone category in the report card. We graders simply comment on it as one aspect within other categories and products, like HomePod or Apple Music. Historically that made sense — when it started , Siri was just a flashy new feature of iOS 5. At this point, though, I think “Siri/Apple Intelligence” clearly deserves to be considered as a category unto itself. One way to think about it: anything that comprises the entire domain of a senior Apple executive probably ought to be its own category on the report card. For Siri and Apple Intelligence, that's John Giannandrea . For another: Apple's own heavy marketing of Apple Intelligence suggests they themselves consider it a category-level aspect of the company. I've suggested this to Snell, and he's considering adding it as a proper category next year. (And, unsurprisingly, given his own sharp writing on the subject , he was already thinking about it before I pinged him.)

If “Siri/Apple Intelligence” were a category for this report card, I'd have graded it a D — and much closer to an F than a C. Longstanding Siri features have not only not gotten better, they've seemingly gotten worse 。 Apple is simply not a relevant player in the explosively popular LLM game. The features under the “Apple Intelligence” umbrella mostly feel like Apple shipped them a full year ahead of readiness simply because the rest of the industry — and Wall Street — is way ahead of them, and they felt the need to ship what they had,准备好了没。 There are a lot of obviously useful potential AI-powered features — ones that integrate between apps, and/or use your personal data on-device — that, thanks to the tightly restricted sandboxing system Apple itself designed for iOS, only Apple itself can provide via AI. It doesn't matter that Apple doesn't offer, say, its own web search engine, because Safari can use whatever search engine you want . It does matter that Siri sucks because only Siri can tightly integrate at the system level with your device, and with your private cross-application data. The saving grace — what kept me from giving this if-it-were-a-category category an F — is that a few of Apple's ML/AI features are actually pretty great. Image search in Photos is excellent, downright amazing at times. The new Clean Up generative AI object/person removal tool in Photos is very good — both technically, and in terms of striking an opinionated balance regarding the nature of photography itself. Private Cloud Compute is a tremendously ambitious initiative — but we haven't seen much fruit from it yet.

Mac: A

The Macs that Apple is shipping are better than ever. The most popular Mac models, by far, are the laptops, and both the MacBook Pro and Air lineups had good years. Even better, both now seem to be on regular annual upgrade schedules: MacBook Pros in the fall, MacBook Airs in the spring. Personally I am especially pleased, borderline ecstatic, regarding the new nano-texture (matte) display option now available on MacBook Pros for $150 extra. (They don't even charge more for the option on the 16-inch models than 14-inch.)

The only hitch in the lineup are the Macs Apple hasn't been shipping: the Mac Studio and Mac Pro remain unchanged since 2023, when the M2 models debuted. My presumption/hunch is they skipped the M3 generation for engineering reasons pertaining to TSMC's first-generation 3nm process, and will be back on track in 2025 with new M4-generation models around WWDC.

MacOS 15 Sequoia, like 14 Sonoma and 13 Ventura before it, is a fine release. Reliable and familiar. Apple Intelligence features that I largely don't use (or at least don't use much yet ) are easily ignored and do not get in the way of what is tried and true about, by far, the greatest computing platform the world has ever看到。

iPhone: A

If it ain't broke, don't fix it. Nothing has been broke regarding the iPhone lineup, and Apple hasn't tried to fix anything.这很好。 Changes for the sake of change are the surest sign of a company in decline. Stagnation and hubris are concerns for any wildly successful product, but it takes confidence to let great design speak for itself without making facile unnecessary changes.

Camera Control is the big new hardware change in the iPhone 16 generation, and while I'd like to see the actual button improve (I think it's too hard to press), in practice I make frequent use of it. I spent some time back on an iPhone 15 over the holidays and I instantly missed having a Camera Control button to launch the Camera app. Also: kudos to Apple for bringing Camera Control to the entire iPhone 16 lineup, not just the Pro models.

iOS 18 is refined, mature, and familiar.

iPad: C

The iPad hardware story is excellent. iPad Pros got the M4 chips months ahead of the Mac, and now have an excellent nano-texture display option. (Please, Apple: bring nano-texture to the iPhone. Take my money.) The iPad Air got a fine update to the M2 chip in May. And the iPad Mini got its first update since 2021, and thus continues to be a product in Apple's lineup .

But iPadOS still strikes me as the no-man's-land platform: nowhere near as capable productivity-wise as a Mac; nowhere near as portable or as conceptually simple as an iPhone. I made a concerted effort not to use my iPad for anything but long-form reading in recent months. I find myself noticeably more productive for it. Trying to work on an iPad, for me, continues to feel like trying to perform surgery while wearing mittens.

Wearables Overall: B

AirPods 4 with ANC are a terrific update. AirPods Pro 2, though years-old hardware, saw significant software improvements this year — most notably, widely acclaimed support for use as certified hearing aids. AirPods continue to exemplify Apple at its best.

Apple Watch: C (last year: B)

Series 10 watches feature a new display that supports once-per-second updates while in energy-saving always-on mode. So the seconds hand on an analog face can “tick” once per second even when the display isn't fully on. But Apple only enabled this ticking seconds indicator on two watch faces, both new to WatchOS 11: Flux and Reflections . Setting aside the fact that I personally don't like either of those faces (Flux in particular seems deliberately obtuse), this is ridiculous. WatchOS 11 offers, by my quick count, at least 33 different watch faces that offer a non-digital seconds hand or indicator. And only 2 of them support the new 1Hz refresh rate? That's bullshit. And it wasn't just a launch thing, because here we are in February, with WatchOS 11.3, and zero additional watch faces have been updated to support it. I will admit to caring far more about always-on seconds hands than most people , but this isn't how a serious watchmaker deals with technical breakthroughs like this new display with a 1Hz refresh rate. Not just most, but every single watch face should have been updated to support ticking seconds. Apple Watch is turning more into a fitness tracker that happens to show the time, and away from serving as a proper watch.

Also: no Ultra 3 this year. The year-old Ultra 2 did gain a very nice black titanium color option, but that's it. Kind of weird for a watch that starts at $800 — and that seems quite popular — to skip a year of silicon improvements.

Vision Pro: B (last year: N/A)

Is it a hit? No, far from it. But I remain unconvinced that Apple ever had much hope that this first Vision device would sell in much higher quantities than it has. The narrative that it's a laughably overpriced bust reminds me of the original Macintosh in 1984, whose $2,500 price tag, adjusted for inflation, works out to over $7,500 in today's dollars. After an initial wave of publicity on launch, the original Macintosh sold so poorly that it was arguably the primary impetus for John Sculley and Apple's board to fire Steve Jobs and exile him from the company. Many pundits of the era confidently proclaimed that the entire concept of a GUI was a gimmick with no future.

Am I predicting that the Vision platform will have as bright and essential a future ahead of it as the Macintosh did in 1984? No. But I suspect it has a bright and essential future ahead of it. The entire concept and paradigm is so new and different that, like the Macintosh 40 years prior, the product had to ship years before a version will be made at a price that appeals to the mass market, and years before there's all that much to do using it.

But, as it stands, Vision Pro today offers an incredible experience for watching traditional movies and shows, and a breakthrough experience for watching spatial content. If Bang & Olufsen sold this product in a form that only played movies — no “spatial computing” — it would cost $10,000 and some people would consider it well worth the price. Spatial computing feels fun to me, but not very productive. That could change, and I suspect “fun but not productive” is how I would have described trying to work on a Macintosh in 1984 vs. an Apple II. And Vision Pro's remarkable (and with VisionOS 2, much improved) Mac Virtual Display feature is a highly-productive environment for work.

I can't give Vision Pro an A for 2024, but I foresee A's in future years.

Home: D (last year: C)

I can't name one improvement to HomeKit or anything Home-related in 2024, and this is a platform sorely in need of many improvements. Fingers crossed for 2025, though. I know there are talented people on that team, and they have to be up to something.

Apple TV: C (last year: B)

I'm a very happy daily (well, nightly) Apple TV user. But what exactly improved or changed in 2024?任何事物？ It may well be fair to say the current hardware — Apple TV 4K 3rd-gen, which shipped in November 2022 — is fine, and this is a hardware platform that only needs updates every 3 or 4 years, but we're grading what happened in 2024.

Also: I feel like Apple has never yet made a truly great remote control for this platform. The current one is their best yet, but it has obvious flaws.

Services: B

TV+ is far from the biggest streaming service, but I'd argue adamantly that it has by far the highest batting average for quality content. Movies are still a weakness: Wolfs should have been great but was mediocre and forgettable. And that was TV+'s best movie of the year. But TV+ series continue to excel: Slow Horses had another crackerjack season, For All Mankind finished a good fourth season, and new shows like Dark Matter , Bad Monkey , and Presumed Innocent were all strong. TV+ is also a great streaming platform for young kids.

iCloud, especially with iCloud Plus, remains secure, fast, and reliable. It enables so much seamless continuity (hence Apple's “ Continuity ” umbrella brand for those features) across devices.

But here we are again, with me repeating the same gripe from previous years: it's miserly that Apple is still offering a mere 5 GB of storage at the free tier, and have left the paid-tier storage allotments unchanged since like forever. I crap bigger than 5 GB. I wonder how many zillions of iPhone users out there don't have device backups because they only have a free iCloud account with 5 GB? The Apple One bundle is a good deal, but the free iCloud tier should be genuinely useful for backing up a modern iPhone. And paid Plus tiers should now offer more storage than they do.

Hardware Reliability: A

No news remains great news in this category.

Apple OS Quality: B
Apple Apps: B

Unchanged comment, and grades, from a year ago: I have concerns and complaints about aspects of the direction Apple's software design is headed (or in some ways, has been now for years), but their software reliability has been very good for me.

One odd trend: several of Apple's newest apps, like Journal and Sports (and now, though outside the temporal boundary for a 2024 report card, Invites) are only available for iPhone. Not even iOS, including iPhone and iPad. Just iPhone. Journal in particular belongs on iPadOS and MacOS, too, where people have hardware keyboards for writing.

Developer Relations: D (last year: C)

Fourth year in a row with basically the same comment: Resentment over App Store policies continues to build. Frustrations with the App Store review process seem unresolved. Apple's goal should be for developer relations to be so good that developers look for excuses to create software exclusively for Apple's platforms. The opposite is happening.

The big change globally this year is the Digital Markets Act going into effect in the EU. I stand apart from many in the Cupertino punditry racket in applauding Apple for their compliance efforts. I think they've complied with a terrible law as best they can while protecting their own vision for how their platforms should be designed and work. (And, of course, protecting their own vision for how Apple should be able to monetize those platforms.) But even I — a guy who thinks Apple has done a remarkable job shipping an enormous amount of work in order to comply with the DMA — can't and won't argue that any of Apple's efforts on the DMA front have repaired or improved its relationship with third-party developers.

Despite the situation being largely unchanged, I've adjusted my grade on this subject from C to D this year, because stagnation is catching up to Apple. More of the same is making matters worse. And I think we saw that with the relative dearth of native app support for Vision Pro. There's a chicken-and-egg problem with a new platform like VisionOS. The best way to generate developer interest in a new platform is to sell a lot of units to a lot of users who are looking for apps to use and games to play. But the best way to sell a lot of hardware units to a lot of users is to have a deep exclusive-to-the-platform ecosystem of both first- and third-party apps and games.

With previous new developer platforms, like iOS and Mac OS X, Apple powered through this initial conundrum by attracting developers who just wanted to create awesome new software for an awesome new platform. That enthusiasm was tempered greatly last year for VisionOS, and I think it was a lot more about how developers feel about Apple and the App Store than how they feel about Vision Pro itself.

Social and Societal Impact: B (last year: A)

Snell's prompt for this category states, “Consider anything you deem appropriate, including education and environmental initiatives, commitment to accessibility and diversity, treatment of Apple's work force, and other political and policy stances.” Apple's efforts on the environmental front continue to strike me as extraordinary. Their accessibility features are so far ahead of the rest of the industry that I don't even know who's in second place. On social issues, by staying true to its longstanding, humane, common sense values, Apple's culture has seemingly remained utterly consistent through a series of tumultuous years in our society at large, during which other companies have ping-ponged first sharply left, and now sharply right.

If I stopped there, that would make for an obvious A grade. But: politics. I understand (I think) Tim Cook's thinking and approach. I wouldn't want his job, and genuinely wonder at times who would. Sing-song congratulatory tweets leave a bitter taste, but I'm amenable to the argument that CEOs must play the cards they've been dealt, not the cards they'd hoped for. If you have to serve shit sandwiches, serve shit sandwiches — but don't tell us they taste like pumpkin pie. Tim Cook can't donate $1 million to Trump's inauguration slush fund when Apple donated a mere $43,200 to Biden's and expect us to do anything but laugh at the supposed justification that Cook “believes the inauguration is a great American tradition, and is donating to the inauguration in the spirit of unity.” That's Tim Cook's hoagie-sized shit sandwich to eat, and it's disrespectful to pitch us on taking a few bites ourselves to help him get through it.

I genuinely believe Cook is doing what's best for Apple, and that's quite literally his job. But it was true during the first Trump administration , and already is again in the second, that what's best for Apple politically is in conflict with what's best for the country and for the world.

  1. In my previous report cards I've described my scale as A to E (A = 5 ... E = 1), but here in the US, schools traditionally (but not always ) omit E as a letter grade and use F as the grade below D, as the obvious shorthand for fail — and, apparently , to disambiguate from some weirdo schools that use a system in which E stands for excellent . (I give that grading system an F.) I never had to give the E vs. F thing much thought before, because I never thought it appropriate to give a failing grade in any category before. But pondering a hypothetical “Siri/Apple Intelligence” category this year got me thinking long and hard about a failing grade. And I realized that should be an F, not an E. ↩︎︎

  2. If you said to me, “ Come on Grubes, you can't think of a single area where Apple did better in 2024 than 2023? Not one? There has to be something... ” I would offer as a response, without hesitation, Apple TV original content. As I wrote just over a month ago, in my final post of the year , I would argue with anyone that the average quality of an Apple TV+ original show is higher than that for any other streaming platform. It really is the new HBO — not the most content, but the best content. That's very Apple .

    But that's not a separate category on the Six Colors Report Card. Apple TV+ falls under “Services” (under which category I call it out for praise in this very report card), and my very high esteem for Apple TV+'s original content doesn't justify bumping up my grade for “Services” as a whole — a sprawling category that, financially, a decade ago become Apple's second-biggest and is seemingly on a trajectory to eventually surpass even the iPhone — from a B to an A.

    I don't see Apple's foray into entertainment production as a distraction. The people at Apple working on computer hardware, software, and services, whether they be engineers, designers, managers, or even senior executives, aren't involved in any way with TV+. And it's not like Apple is cash-starved and diverting limited resources to entertainment production budgets at the expense of product development or R&D. Apple, the most valuable and profitable company in the world, can act a bit like a conglomerate without losing focus on its core business of making the world's best computers, on which customers enjoy the world's best computing experiences. TV+ is an important leg on the stool of reasons for people to subscribe to an Apple One services bundle. But, still, it's at least a little worrisome that the area where I feel Apple most improved last year is one that is utterly unrelated to that core business.

    Excellence, no matter how long sustained, is always precarious — delicate and fragile — and on the verge of succumbing to hubris and Father Time. ↩︎︎
